posts.title: About
posts.markdown:
> “And those who were seen dancing, were thought to be crazy, by those who could not hear the music.” - Friedrich Nietzsche ## Our DNA Here at THINK Grenada we believe that a thorough understanding of prevalent issues affecting our society will reduce speculation and harmonize the thoughts and actions of the people, enabling us to rise as a united nation. While we want to focus on articles that primarily focus on prevalent matters, we also believe that the people can be unified through positive entertainment and interesting facts. This can also serve to promote our tiny island for what it really is, the best island in the world! ## Our Merits

Timely

*Providing information when is is needed most*

Honest

*Standing for truth, no matter who tells it*

Inclusive

*Every person and every topic is welcome*

Novel

*Delivering unusually high quality content*

Kosher

*Keeping it aboveboard*
##We want to hear from you! Contact us at [thinkgrenada@gmail.com](mailto:thinkgrenada@gmail.com) with your feedback, suggestions and suggested posts for a chance to be featured! Just include your name and your favourite quote for a chance to be featured on our homepage for two whole weeks!
posts.html:
“And those who were seen dancing, were thought to be crazy, by those who could not hear the music.” - Friedrich Nietzsche

Our DNA

Here at THINK Grenada we believe that a thorough understanding of prevalent issues affecting our society will reduce speculation and harmonize the thoughts and actions of the people, enabling us to rise as a united nation.

While we want to focus on articles that primarily focus on prevalent matters, we also believe that the people can be unified through positive entertainment and interesting facts. This can also serve to promote our tiny island for what it really is, the best island in the world!

Our Merits

Timely

Providing information when is is needed most

Honest

Standing for truth, no matter who tells it

Inclusive

Every person and every topic is welcome

Novel

Delivering unusually high quality content

Kosher

Keeping it aboveboard

We want to hear from you!

Contact us at thinkgrenada@gmail.com with your feedback, suggestions and suggested posts for a chance to be featured!

Just include your name and your favourite quote for a chance to be featured on our homepage for two whole weeks!
posts.meta_description: THINK Grenada is the premier platform for the people of Grenada and the Caribbean to share and enjoy quality and relevant articles.

posts.title: Join Us
posts.markdown:
<!--Goats are inquisitive, intelligent and readily revert to the wild (become feral) if given the opportunity, which is rare for domesticated animals.-->
##Be part of the herd!

THINK Grenada's main purpose is to deliver quality and informative material with the end goal of having a population with a clear understanding of the issues that face the country. This will give us the ability to make decisions that are best for the country and avoid the rampant spread of rumors. 

We also strive to bring our people together through light and entertaining articles from time to time.

To achieve this, we will need your help! While we enjoy sharing our knowledge with you and hope to continue doing so, we also realize that to have a real impact we will need others to share their knowledge and experiences with everyone as well.

We invite you to join the herd and help us to provide our valued readers with your quality articles, interesting insights and awe inspiring stories!

##Who can become a THINK Grenada writer?

Anyone! Here at THINK Grenada, we believe that anyone with a unique perspective on a certain topic, an interesting tale, a spotlight story or just something they want the people to know are welcome.

We do not necessarily require you to have any experience as an established writer or blogger. However, to fit with our [merits](/about), we require that your content be of high quality for it to be published.

This goes without saying that NOT all submissions or applicants will be accepted. In order to maintain a high quality for our articles, every article will undergo a review by our panel of reviewers before acceptance.

Because we want your story to be heard, we will occasionally offer our expertise and make suggestions to the writers whose content is great but lacking in other areas.

We are against content theft and plagiarism. Please write in your own words and give necessary credit in your work. Only original and unpublished articles will be accepted. 

Once your article has been published, it will belong to THINK Grenada and you cannot republish it without our written permission.

##Instructions

###I want to be a regular writer
For those who are interested in writing for THINK Grenada on a continual basis, contact us at [thinkgrenada@gmail.com](mailto:thinkgrenada@gmail.com) with a concise description of yourself, your contact information, your expertise/skills and your topics of specialization and interest. Attach URLs to some of your work or send your portfolio/examples. 

We will contact you to provide you with detailed guidelines and feedback.

Once accepted, we will provide detailed guidelines so you will know exactly what we expect and what we are interested in.

###I want to be a one off writer
For those who just want their article to be featured, but not sure if they would like to become an official writer, contact us at [thinkgrenada@gmail.com](mailto:thinkgrenada@gmail.com) with your piece. 

You can optionally provide a concise description of yourself which would be added to the post.

###I doh kno how too write
No problem! Contact us at [thinkgrenada@gmail.com](mailto:thinkgrenada@gmail.com) with your idea and we'll have someone help you through the process!

##Why write for THINK Grenada?

###Visibility - Viraility - Recognition

Each writer is acknowledged at the bottom of the article as the author along with a link to their official website and social media account as well as a short but detailed biography.

###Showcase your skill

Writing for THINK Grenada will provide great exposure to a continuously growing audience. This means that you can impress potential employers, clients and other interested parties who view your work.

###Be part of the change
You can play an integral role in the growth of the nation by sharing your talents, skills and knowledge! We know you want the best for Grenada so let's help enable our country together!

##Our topics

In order to maintain the quality and consistency of our articles, each article written for THINK Grenada will need to follow our guidelines before it is published. As such, we cannot promise that all submitted articles will be published.

To ensure that you don't waste your time, below are some guidelines you can follow.

###Our interest is anything Grenada

####Articles: 

- Success stories & Inspirational posts
- Case studies 
- Interesting facts
- Useful tips
- Tutorials
- Showcases/Roundups
- Unique topics and fresh ideas that provoke intellectual discussion (E.g. opinion pieces, philosophies and history etc.)

If you have the knowledge, talent, skill and some time, we have an audience waiting to hear what you have to share with them.

###Yuh ready fi dis? 
If you want to join the heard and be part of the change, whether as a writer, reviewer, mentor, donor or partner (did we miss any?), we would be glad to welcome you to the THINK team!

####Contact us now at [thinkgrenada@gmail.com](mailto:thinkgrenada@gmail.com)!

posts.title: Should Grenada legalize homosexual marriage?
posts.markdown:
Having a long colonial past, Grenada was last colonized by the British. Being colonized as a "Christian" society, Grenada thus inherited most of its abritrary laws and customs. Since independence in the 1970's, most of these laws and customs still exist today and are at the bedrock of moral thinking within the society. In most western societies same sex relations are deemed as completely normal, once both adults are consensually involved. However, in Grenada under the Grenada Criminal Code, Section 431, those acts are considered "unnatural". Whether or not the individuals involved are adults and make the conscious decisions to do so. It's is important to note that Grenada got that same law from a country that has now, through education deem homosexual acts, "NATURAL" and has revised and decarded those laws that are incompatible with rational intelligent thinking. 
I would argue that since Grenada being a apart of the commonwealth, having an active queen's representation in the state, we should hereby revised those laws and end the discrimination and stigmatization of people with homosexual orientation.
While most people in Grenada aren't interested in science, 
it has shown that homosexuality is completely normal among all species( including homosapiens, which we are), and occurs with a 10% frequency. In fact, there are good evolutionary reasons for homosexuality. While this knowledge may not be reconcilable with religious philosophy, providing people get away from emotional responses and take a rational look at the phenomenon of same sex relationship, most people won't be bothered by it. 
There are numerous arguments that can go against homosexual relationships. On the other hand, until 1973 the diagnostic and statistical manual of mental illnesses(DSM) in the USA, treated homosexuality as a mental illness. Homosexuality was voted out of the manual for non scientific reasons in 1974 and at their annual convention. Until recently evolutionary biologists has gathered enough scientific information in regards to homosexuality and deeming it,  completely normal among every species on the planet earth. Brings me to the question, why then should we disdain people who practice homosexuality?
















Photo Credit:
https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&source=images&cd=&ved=0ahUKEwi75qKwu6DOAhVGbR4KHd1YAQ4QjB0IBg&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.shutterstock.com%2Fpic-291179036%2Fstock-vector-gay-marriage-rainbow-homosexual-flat-icon-for-apps-and-websites.html&psig=AFQjCNHu8l1erMKZDsOB3VKgbnbcWMlvWw&ust=1470149338298838&rct=j

posts.title: The lingering effects of colonialism and slavery. Part one.
posts.markdown:
As citizens of the tri-island state of Grenada it can be argued that most of our traditional norms and practices are directly derived from our colonial encounters. We can examine this from a number  of the areas. Firstly:

RELIGION - Grenada is a state, where most people follow many religious philosophies, predominantly Christianity. Looking at this philosophy pragmaticly, one can realize that as a people we adopted this particular religious ideology in the period of slavery. And as harsh/unrealistic as this may sound and through very cruel processes, we were coerced to accept this ideology. Many people today in our "Christian" society neglect these realities, to console themselves into thinking that the Christian religion is our "true religion"; nothing is further from
The truth! As people of African descent, which for some Grenadian's they don't accept being called Africans because for some reason they interpet they their geo-political
place with their race. Thus, they prefer to be called grenadians. In this shocking revelation, one can see how regressive the effects of colonialism and slavery has left our society. In that aspect we deny our own identity, for an artificial state name, given by the people who brought us here in the first place. Some persons argue that Caribbean nationalistic ideologies are nothing but politically correct names for being a slave in modern day. There are no ethnographical evidence to support these artificial states, the customs and practices are not original practices of the people. These are false-consciousness adopted by a people from their master after being subjected (and in some cases are still undergo) to inhumane treatment for centuries.
Similarly there are other religious ideologies that are steadily taken hold, such as Islam, Mormonism and other various sects of Christianity, what is striking to note is the direct correlation between fundamentally religious societies and poverty a 2010 Gallup poll suggests. An independent study by Dr.Tom Rees, published in the journal of religion and society, suggests that in places without strong social safety nets to
Provide people with opportunities for upward mobility, people are more likely to rely on religion for comfort. Both the poll and the study highlighted correlations between religion and poverty. So how then, do we get ourselves as a people out of this hole? 






 Photo Credit: https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&source=images&cd=&ved=0ahUKEwibpZjLuqDOAhWNsB4KHd6eB6EQjB0IBg&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.slayerment.com%2Fwhites-ended-slavery&psig=AFQjCNGiUiMWQlpJnNRRpVTO4PleG8DvjQ&ust=1470148876262308&rct=j
